name: Individual Berry Crisps
headline: Individual Berry Crisps
keywords: Easy Dessert Recipes,Dessert,Easy Baking,Fruit Dessert Recipes,Fruit,Baking,Nut Recipes,Blueberry,Raspberry Recipes,Summer,Low-Fat,Low Sodium
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup plus 2 cups crisp topping, recipe follows

recipeInstructions.text: Place the frozen berries, sugar, cornstarch and 1/2 cup of the crisp topping into a medium mixing bowl and stir to combine. Divide the mixture evenly between 4 (7 to 8-ounce) ramekins. Top each ramekin with 1/2 cup of the remaining crisp topping. Place the ramekins on a sheet pan and bake on the middle rack of the oven for 30 to 35 minutes or until the fruit is bubbling and the topping is browned. Allow the crisps to cool for 15 minutes before serving.
1 1/2 cups chopped nuts such as; walnuts, pecans, or almonds
1 1/2 cups crushed crackers, gingersnaps or cereal
4 ounces unsalted butter, cubed and chilled

Place the flour, sugar, nuts and crackers into a large mixing bowl and combine. Work the butter into the dry ingredients with your hands until it is crumbly. Store in the refrigerator for up to a week. Use as topping for crisps, cobblers or grunts.

review.reviewBody: I used strawberries & blueberries - a delicious combination.  I also did a mix of slivered almonds & graham crackers.  This is a winner!
I made one 8x8 pan of this delicious dessert, using gluten free flour and cereal.  It was so good.  Loved the topping and fruit together.  Alton is a Master.
would like to see Nutiritional values...

Awesome! I made it for a dinner party and everyone loved it. I used Special K almond cereal and To cut some calories, I made it with light butter and it came out perfect. I topped it with light vanilla ice cream. I will make again!

I have never been inspired to review a dish until now. This is SO delicious, simple, and impressive. I used frozen raspberries and gingersnaps for the crisp topping, and it was delightful in every way. Will definitely continue to make and experiment with different fruits!

Used gingersnaps and mixed wild blueberries, raspberries and blackberries, more than called for. I also used half unbleached and half whole wheat flour and less sugar. Absolutely my favorite dessert ever! I made four five oz ramekins for company (who asked for the recipe) and had enough berries and topping left over to make three more to take to my mother the next day. She did stop short of licking the ramekin but she did rave about how good it was. I was afraid the gingersnaps would detract from the berries, but the combo was absolutely perfect!
I made this today for my family and it turned out SO GOOD!! I used blackberries and raspberries. My husband and my 3 1/2 y.o. son loved it! Will definitely make again...thanks Alton! ;-

Made this two nights in a row, both times for guests. The first night, I used mostly strawberries. It was way too sweet! The second night I used blueberries and blackberries. I also used only a few spoonfuls of sugar on the berries (rather than 1/4 cup. It was much better this time! Still, I wasn't blown away. I've had better!

We followed Alton's recipe to the letter and the berry crisps turned out great. Everyone at the table gave us rave reviews for this wonderful dessert. From other reviewers it sounds like this recipe is adaptable and will work well with other berries and stone fruits.

Our only deviation from the recipe was using 6 ounce ramekins instead of 8 ounce ramekins. However, it only meant having more crisp topping left over.

The combination of blueberries and raspberries melded deliciously with the gingersnaps and walnuts used in the topping. The crisps paired excellently with vanilla ice cream.

This might be my favorite berry dessert of all time and it's so tasty and simple, it might be one of my favorite desserts overall. The first time I made it, I paired it with a crème anglaise and it was magnificent, but simple whipped cream or vanilla ice cream would be just as yummy. I also made a variation with no nuts or cereal, substituting oatmeal and it was very good as well.
Really Good make it over and over.

I have made this with all sorts of fruits--my latest was nectarines and blackberries--both fresh--and all sorts of cereals--and it is sooooooo good! I also make it in a large baking pan to save time. It also keeps well (as long as my husband get at it too often! A wonderful and easy recipe.
Yummy.  I was a little worried as I have not made anything like that before, but it was so easy and tasty.  A keeper.
My boyfriend and I loved this recipe for Berry Crisp. I use fresh blueberries instead of frozen. It goes well with a scoop of vanilla icecream. Great desert all year round.

This was a hit and so easy!  I used frozen marionberries and I used graham crackers instead of ginger snaps (that was all we had.  They turned out great and we added a little vanilla i.c. to top it off.
Very easy and delish, used left over fresh berries (strawberries, blackberries, blue berries and raspberries), little orange zest and oatmeal for the cereal.

Made these last night and loved them.   Used ginger snap cookies.  Make sure you crush them a lot.  Used fresh blueberries and fresh blackberries.  Other than fresh fruit instead of frozen I followed the recipe exactly.  Very easy to make and delicious with a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top.

LOVED the crispy topping.  I used Grape Nut Flakes.  I actually used fresh fruit.  I took about a pint and a half of blueberries and a pint and a half of blackberries and made two separate deserts.  Each fruit went into a pot with 1 1/2 cups of water and 1/2 cup of sugar.  I boiled them.  Then removed from heat and added a few Tablespoons of cornstarch to thicken.  Then I spooned 4 ramekins with the sweet blackberry filling and an oval baking dish with the blueberry filling.  The crisp topping made enough for both dishes!  I added the crispy topping and baked as Mr. Brown suggested.  The final product was amazing and loved by all...adults and children.  Great recipe!
Awesome and so easy to make!  I like to use whatever berries, fresh or frozen, that I have on hand.  Really easy to change them out.
One of the easiest recipes I have ever made and one that my kids love I usually make it around the holidays but it is a great comfort food
This is a fabulous recipe! I make mine with a mixture of blueberries and raspberries with sliced almonds and amaretto cookies. Great to make extra topping for the freezer.

I love this recipe, I'm a huge fan of Alton, he's one of my major my food idols. Thses crips were delectable i really loved it because it wasnt overly sweet so the natural flavor of the berries stood out.

--Rachel Brown Kiehl, www.theplumjam.blogspot.com <--check it out ;)
I made this recipe exactly as written and it was amazing.  The berries really stood out and it was not overly sweet.  I used cornflakes and pecans and almonds for the crisp.  Delicious!
Follow the recipe.  I took the advice of a reviewer and added 3 tbsp. of corn starch and used oatmeal,  I ended with a tight mass that was so bland I ended up throwing it away.

I made this for 4ht of July, with a fresh mix of blackberries, raspberries and blueberries. Used Oatmeal in the topping and baked it in a 9 x 13 pan. Everyone loved it. I even made a diabetic version using Splenda for baking for my father in law. He was in heaven having his own 9 x 9 pan to eat and take some home.
Thanks Alton for the great recipe!

This is an absolutely yummy dessert!  I bought a mixture of frozen berries from Costco (blueberries, raspberries and marionberries), made the crumble with gingersnaps and served it to guests we had for dinner along with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream.  We all raved about how yummy it is!  It's also an easy dessert to prepare.  I will definitely be making this again.
Everyone's favorite. It perfect for a cold fall or winter day. Its already been requested again.

I used fresh raspberry instead of frozen. Also, my ramekins were of size 6oz.  So, I needed only half of the crisp topping even though I used 8 ramekins.  Saved the other half of crisp topping in the refrigerator with tight cover.  I made another batch of 8 ramekins  a week later. Was great!! will make it again with all the berries around!

I just made these but with nectarines (which are in season) instead of berries and gingersnaps and oatmeal in the topping (no nuts b/c I didn't have 'em in my kitchen). So. Good. With this though (and peaches) I would add cinnamon to the fruit mixture before baking which would just up the ante I think.

I love AB and his recipes ALWAYS work...without fail.

Just more proof.

I had just purchased 4 ramekins and had also purchased some blueberries at the farmers market. My husband came home with more blueberries after work so I decided to find a recipe that would use both and this one fit the bill perfectly! I of course used fresh instead of frozen blueberries and used graham crackers crushed with crushed pecans. My ramekins were only 6 oz. and for me that was the perfect size. I will use a bit less sugar next time but I am also pleased that I have left over topping to make them again this week. That is a nice plus. This was a very easy recipe with lovely results.

These were great.  Mine made way too much topping, but I'm just freezing the extra for next time.  I made mine with raspberries and blackberries, so using gingersnaps seemed a bit odd.  I used Archway Iced Oatmeal cookies instead, and they were great.  I think the gingersnaps would be perfect if you used apples or pears.
I love this recipe. I always keep extra crumb mixture in my freezer so I can just pick up a bag of fruit and have a great dessert!

I followed the directions to the letter with one exception: I used a pastry blender to mix in the butter for the topping.  I used gingersnaps for the crisp topping.  I have been making fruit crisps for many years.  This was by far the best one I have ever made.  I don't know if it's because of the gingersnaps (I usually use oatmeal) or because some of the topping is mixed in with the fruit.  Whatever--it's now my favorite fruit crisp recipe.  1/2 recipe made 3-7oz ramekins with left-over topping.  Very easy.  I served it with a scope of vanilla ice cream.  A great dessert.

I added chocolate.  I went with frozen raspberries, Special K Pecan cereal, pecans & walnuts. Then I put a few bittersweet chocolate chips in each ramekin, so they don't overpower anything, but add a fun surprise. It was really easy and so delicious!
This is a great dessert!  It's loaded with flavor and not too doughy.  I actually made one big crisp in a round corningware dish since I don't have individual ramikins.  It turned out amazing!

i am pretty new to cooking and so i thought i would give this a try.  the recipe was easy to follow and the cobbler turned out great.  i used organic apple cinnamon granola as my cereal.  the only thing i would say was not just right was that it turned out slightly dry, but i think it was probably my oven.
This was so easy my grandchildren were able to help. A real keeper!!!

I used blueberries and made it in an oval baking dish instead of the ramikins. It was really tasty but I felt there was too much sugar.  Perhaps I didn't mix everything well enough because I could still taste some of the grit from the sugar. I'd make again and try less sugar to see if that makes a difference.

When I prepared this the first time, it was prepared in an oval corning dish. I poored the remainder of the crisp to form a THICK layer on top of the blueberry mixture. By the time the topping was browned, the blueberries underneath were overcooked and dry. I couldn't tell when the berries were bubling due to the topping layer.

The next-time, I cooked without the topping in order to eyeball when the blueberries were done. It turned out great, and my family would actually eat it.

If you add a layer of crisp topping, I'm not sure how one could tell if the blueberries underneath were done.. Maybe my layer of topping was too thick.

I made this as a single dish dessert for 9 at a dinner party.  Baked it while everyone was having dinner and it came out of the oven right on cue for the dessert round.  Everyone loved it, and it will be made again!  Went with the basic blueberry this time around

This takes a simple fruit crisp to a whole new level.  The berries may need a little more sugar than the recipe calls for if they are really tart.  I used 1/2 cup of sugar and increased the cornstarch to 3 tbsp.  I used chopped pecans in my crisp and substituted quick cooking oats for the crackers, cookies, cereal etc...   The topping tastes like Pepperidge Farm Verona Cookies!  Simple enough that my 6 year old did most of the work, yet delicious and pretty enough for company!  Serve with vanilla bean ice cream for a real treat!
Great dessert - next time, I'll add lowfat vanilla ice cream!
This is so easy it makes itself. I used mixed berries instead of just blueberries it worked great.

I love Alton Brown!  And this recipe!  The little cobblers were so quick and delicious!  Everyone loved them!  I used Costco's triple berry frozen fruit--blueberries, blackberries and raspberries.  Worked perfect!  Thanks Alton!
So easy -- double the crisp part when you mix it up.  Freeze it and you are ready with a fast dessert - just get the berries.
These are great! Easy for dinner guests!
At first u will think these are hard to make, not a at all.  Simple and amazing in taste!

This is a fun way to make and serve a crispy berry dessert.  I used the frozen raspberries and the result was a sweetly tart dish.  We topped it with vanilla ice cream.  I am looking forward to trying it with other kinds of fruit.  Raspberries are not my favorite, but it was all I had on hand today.  I used crisp butter cookies for the cookie ingredient.
I doubled the recipe and filled many more that four custard cups worth.  I used the blueberry and raspberry combination.  It results in a very wonderful sweet, tart, and flavorful dessert!

I used generic ginger snaps and shelled walnuts from Wal-mart for the crisp,and a frozen berry mix from Harris Teeter for the filling. Everything turned out great, but I got five 7oz ramekins instead of 4 from the recipe, and had topping left over. But, it tasted great.

video.name: Individual Berry Crisps
video.description: Alton Brown shares the secret to delicious individual berry crisps.
